sections.title: What are comparatives?
sections.content:
Comparatives are used to compare **two people, things or situations**. In English we usually add **-er** to short adjectives (taller, faster) or use **more + adjective** with longer adjectives (more interesting, more expensive). We often use **than** after a comparative: taller than, more expensive than.

Examples:
• My sister is **taller than** me.
• This exercise is **easier than** the last one.
• Prague is **smaller than** London.
• This film is **more interesting than** the book.

sections.title: How to form comparatives
sections.content:
1) **Short adjectives (1 syllable, and some 2-syllable like "happy")**
• Add **-er**: tall → taller, long → longer, cheap → cheaper.
• If the word ends in **-e**, just add **-r**: nice → nicer, large → larger.
• If it ends **consonant + single vowel + consonant**, double the final consonant: big → bigger, hot → hotter, thin → thinner.
• If it ends in **-y**, change y → i + **-er**: happy → happier, easy → easier, funny → funnier.

2) **Long adjectives (usually 2+ syllables)**
• Use **more + adjective**: more expensive, more difficult, more comfortable, more interesting.

3) **Irregular comparatives**
• good → **better**
• bad → **worse**
• far → **farther/further**
• little → **less**
• many/much → **more**

sections.title: Using comparatives in sentences
sections.content:
We usually compare **A and B** with a comparative + **than**:

• A comparative adjective + than:
  – Tom is **taller than** his brother.
  – Today is **colder than** yesterday.
  – This task is **more difficult than** the last one.

We can also use **not as ... as** for negative comparisons:

• She is **not as tall as** her sister. (= her sister is taller)
• This exam is **not as hard as** the last one.

We can make the comparison stronger with words like **much, a lot, far**:

• This book is **much better than** the film.
• The new flat is **far bigger than** the old one.

sections.title: More comparative patterns (advanced)
sections.content:
At higher levels we use comparatives in more complex patterns:

• **Comparatives with adverbs**: She speaks **more slowly than** before. He drives **faster than** his brother.
• **Gradable differences**: a bit/slightly/rather vs much/a lot/far
  – This test is **a bit easier than** the last one.
  – The new system is **much more efficient than** the old one.
• **The ... the ... structure**: The **more** you practise, the **better** your English gets. The **faster** we work, the **sooner** we can finish.
• **Than + clause**: The meeting took longer than we **expected / thought / planned**.

These patterns help you sound more natural and precise when comparing things in advanced English.

sections.title: Superlatives – the best, the most, the least
sections.content:
Superlatives are used to compare **one person or thing with all the others in a group**. We usually use **the + superlative**:

• Short adjectives: add **-est**
  – tall → **the tallest**
  – big → **the biggest** (double the final consonant)
  – easy → **the easiest** (y → iest)

• Long adjectives: **the most + adjective**
  – **the most interesting**, **the most expensive**, **the most comfortable**

• Irregular superlatives:
  – good → **the best**
  – bad → **the worst**
  – far → **the farthest / the furthest**
  – little → **the least**
  – many/much → **the most**

We often use superlatives with expressions like **in + place/group** or **I’ve ever + past participle**:

• She is **the tallest in the class**.
• This is **the most difficult test I've ever done**.
• It's **the best restaurant in town**.
• That was **the worst day of my life**.

sections.title: Typical Czech learner errors
sections.content:
Czech often uses 'víc' with an adjective. In English we **cannot** usually put 'more' and '-er' together, and we must choose the correct pattern:

• **Double comparative:** Wrong: *more easier*, *more better*, *more smaller*. Right: **easier**, **better**, **smaller**.
• **More with short adjectives:** Wrong: *more tall*, *more cold*. Right: **taller**, **colder**.
• **-er with long adjectives:** Wrong: *interestinger*, *expensiver*. Right: **more interesting**, **more expensive**.
• **Missing "than":** Wrong: *She is taller me.* Right: **She is taller than me.**
• **Using "like" instead of "as" in negative comparisons:** Wrong: *She is not so tall like her brother.* Right: **She is not as tall as her brother.**

Tip: Learn which adjectives are short (take -er) and which are long (more + adjective). Watch out for double comparatives (more + -er).

questions.question: Which sentence is correct?

options.a: This exercise is more easier than the last one.
options.b: This exercise is easier than the last one.
options.c: This exercise is more easy than the last one.
options.d: This exercise is easyer than the last one.

questions.explanation: Easy → easier. We cannot use both more + adjective and -er together.

questions.question: Choose the correct comparative.
questions.explanation: Tall is a short adjective → taller than.

questions.question: Which is the correct form?
questions.explanation: Interesting is a long adjective → more interesting than.

questions.question: Complete the sentence: 'His English is ____ mine.'
questions.explanation: Good → better (irregular comparative).

questions.question: Which negative comparison is correct?

options.a: She is not so tall like her brother.
options.b: She is not as tall as her brother.
options.c: She is not so taller as her brother.
options.d: She is not as tall like her brother.

questions.explanation: The pattern is not as + adjective + as (not so ... like is a common Czech-influenced error).

gapfill.title: Practice: Gap fill – Form the comparative (basic)

questions.question: 1. My sister is ____ (tall) than me.
questions.explanation: Tall → taller (short adjective + -er) + than.

questions.question: 2. This exercise is ____ (easy) than the last one.
questions.explanation: Easy → easier (y → ier).

questions.question: 3. London is ____ (big) than Prague.
questions.explanation: Big → bigger (double the final consonant).

questions.question: 4. Today is ____ (hot) than yesterday.
questions.explanation: Hot → hotter (double the final consonant).

questions.question: 5. This task is ____ (interesting) than the others.
questions.explanation: Interesting is long → more interesting than.

questions.question: 6. His English is ____ (good) than mine.
questions.explanation: Good → better.

questions.question: 7. The situation is ____ (bad) than before.
questions.explanation: Bad → worse.

questions.question: 8. This street is ____ (narrow) than the main road.
questions.explanation: Narrow → narrower (add -er).

questions.question: 9. The film was ____ (boring) than I expected.
questions.explanation: Boring is long → more boring than.

questions.question: 10. My flat is ____ (far) from the centre than yours.
questions.explanation: Far → farther/further.

questions.question: 11. This exam is ____ (difficult) than the last one.
questions.explanation: Difficult is long → more difficult than.

questions.question: 12. She is ____ (old) than she looks.
questions.explanation: Old → older.

questions.question: 13. This book is ____ (far / interesting) than the film.
questions.explanation: Use a modifier (far/much) + more interesting than.

questions.question: 14. The new system is ____ (a bit / efficient) than the old one.
questions.explanation: Use a bit/slightly + more efficient than.

questions.question: 15. Rewrite using 'not as ... as': 'Her car is cheaper than mine.'
answers: My car is not as cheap as hers.
My car isn't as cheap as hers.
questions.explanation: Cheaper than → my car is not as cheap as hers.

questions.question: 16. Rewrite using 'the more ... the more ...': 'If you practise more, your English will get better.'
answers: The more you practise, the better your English gets.
The more you practise, the better your English will get.
questions.explanation: If you practise more, your English will get better → The more you practise, the better your English (will) get(s).

questions.question: 17. Complete: 'The ____ (soon) we start, the ____ (soon) we can finish.'
answers: The sooner we start, the sooner we can finish.
the sooner we start, the sooner we can finish
questions.explanation: The sooner ..., the sooner ...

questions.question: 18. Complete: 'He drives ____ (carefully) than he used to.'
questions.explanation: Carefully is an adverb → more carefully than ...

questions.question: 19. The meeting took ____ (long) than we expected.
questions.explanation: Comparative with than + clause: longer than we expected.

questions.question: 20. This year's results are ____ (slightly / good) than last year's.
questions.explanation: Use a small degree adverb + better (slightly/a bit better than).

questions.question: 21. She is ____ (tall) girl in the class.
questions.explanation: Tall → the tallest (superlative with the).

questions.question: 22. This is ____ (good) restaurant in town.
questions.explanation: Good → the best (irregular superlative).

questions.question: 23. That was ____ (bad) exam I've ever done.
answers: the worst exam I've ever done.
questions.explanation: Bad → the worst. Typical pattern: the worst ... I've ever done.

questions.question: 24. It’s ____ (interesting) book I've ever read.
answers: the most interesting book I've ever read.
the most interesting book I have ever read.
the most interesting book I’ve ever read.
questions.explanation: Long adjective → the most interesting (superlative) + I've ever read.

questions.question: 25. January is usually ____ (cold) month of the year here.
questions.explanation: Cold → the coldest.

questions.question: 26. This question is ____ (difficult) one in the test.
questions.explanation: Difficult → the most difficult (long adjective).

questions.question: 27. He lives in ____ (far) village from the city.
questions.explanation: Far → the farthest / the furthest.

questions.question: 28. This is one of ____ (expensive) hotels in the city.
questions.explanation: Pattern: one of the + superlative plural → one of the most expensive hotels.

questions.question: 1. Wrong: 'This exercise is more easier than the last one.' Correct the sentence.
answers: This exercise is easier than the last one.
This exercise is easier than the last one
questions.explanation: Don't use more + -er together. Just easier.

questions.question: 2. Wrong: 'He is more tall than his brother.' Correct the sentence.
answers: He is taller than his brother.
He is taller than his brother
questions.explanation: Tall is short → taller than, not more tall than.

questions.question: 3. Wrong: 'Today is more cold than yesterday.' Correct the sentence.
questions.explanation: Cold is short → colder than, not more cold than.

questions.question: 4. Wrong: 'Prague is more small than London.' Correct the sentence.
questions.explanation: Small is short → smaller than, not more small than.

questions.question: 5. Wrong: 'This problem is worser than the last one.' Correct the sentence.
answers: This problem is worse than the last one.
This problem is worse than the last one
questions.explanation: Bad → worse, not worser.

questions.question: 6. Wrong: 'She is not so tall like her brother.' Correct the sentence.
answers: She is not as tall as her brother.
She is not as tall as her brother
questions.explanation: Pattern: not as + adjective + as (not so ... like).

questions.question: 7. Wrong: 'This road is the more dangerous than that one.' Correct the sentence.
answers: This road is more dangerous than that one.
This road is more dangerous than that one
questions.explanation: Comparative: more dangerous than (no the before a simple comparative).

questions.question: 8. Wrong: 'Her English is better than my sister.' Correct the sentence.
answers: Her English is better than my sister's.
Her English is better than my sister's English.
questions.explanation: We compare English with English: better than my sister's (English).
